properties.sex: Data are based on a fiscal year (April 1 through March 31). For more information on the concepts, methods and quality of the data contained in this table, consult the Definitions, data sources and methods http://www.statcan.gc.ca/imdb-bmdi/3323-eng.htm. Additional information related to youth corrections is included in the report "Youth Correctional Statistics in Canada, 2010-2011".

Admissions are collected each time a person begins any type of custodial or community supervision, and describe and measure the case-flow in correctional agencies over time. The same person can be included several times in the admission counts where the individual moves from one type of legal status to another (e.g., from open to secure custody) or re-enters the system in the same year. As such, admissions represent the number of entries within a fiscal year to sentenced custody, to remand, and to community supervision regardless of the individual's preceding or following legal status.

Beginning in 2003/2004, Newfoundland and Labrador data were provided through Integrated Correctional Services Survey (ICSS), and as such, caution is recommended when comparing these data against those from other years.

In Ontario data began to be provided through Integrated Correctional Services Survey (ICSS in 2004/2005). Prior to 2004/2005 Ontario data were submitted separately by two provincial ministries: the Ministry of Children and Youth Services (MCYS) which was responsible for youth who were 12 to 15 years old at the time of the offence, and the Ministry of Community Safety and Correctional Services (MCSCS) which was responsible for 16 to 17-year-olds. Since 2004/2005 data for both age groups have been submitted by a single ministry and appear in this table as Ontario only. Ontario did not report pre-trial detention for 12 to 15-year-olds prior to 2004/2005 and data for 12 to 15-year-olds was not provided for 2002/2003. As a result, caution is recommended when making trend comparisons for Ontario and Canada.
Totals for secure and open custody include Youth Criminal Justice Act (YCJA) and Young Offenders Act (YOA) based admissions.

For New Brunswick, two changes in reporting systems should be noted; the first in 2000/2001 and the second in 2003/2004, the later representing the adoption of the Integrated Correctional Services Survey (ICSS). As such, caution is recommended when making trend comparisons for New Brunswick.

Alberta uses a different counting methodology whereby an admission to custody is counted once, regardless of change in status. As such, in 2010/2011 Alberta reported 1,666 remand admissions; 231 remand later sentenced (open or secure) admissions, and; 52 sentenced (open or secure) only admissions. This report has included Alberta's remand later sentenced admissions in both the number of admissions to remand and then again in the number of admissions to sentenced (open or secure) custody, resulting in a higher number of admissions than that reported by the jurisdiction. Alberta community data are being provided through Integrated Correctional Services Survey (ICSS) as of 2004/2005, and as such, caution is recommended when comparing these data against those from other years.
British Columbia probation data for 2003/2004 include all community supervision.
